awd_titl_txt: EDGE:  Functional genomics in Polistes wasps, a model system in integrative organismal biology
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent technological advances in DNA sequencing have fueled important new discoveries in many fields of biology.  The "genomic revolution" has provided a wealth of data to unravel the mysteries of how diverse organisms evolve, interact, and respond to their environments.  However, a major hurdle has been that the vast majority of studies are correlative.  Tools allowing researchers to pinpoint causal associations between genes and traits are limited. This research will apply the latest technology to study gene function in an emerging model for organismal biology, Polistes wasps. These insects, commonly known as paper wasps, are well-studied, cosmopolitan, social insects.  Because of their abundance in human environments, ease of experimental manipulation, and rapidly developing genomic resources, they are poised to address many integrative organismal biology questions (including speciation, behavior, development, and neuroscience). The project will employ two cutting edge technologies for gene manipulation along with focused efforts to breed and maintain colonies in the laboratory, in order to test causality for several genes associated with traits such as coloration, learning, aggression, and development. This work can have a catalytic impact on a growing community of researchers interested in using social insects to address a wide variety of questions in organismal biology, applied entomology and agriculture. Training and mentoring in the latest methodologies will be provided to one postdoctoral researcher, one graduate student, one research technician, and numerous undergraduates.  Results, resources and methods will be disseminated widely to the research community through symposia, lab exchanges, and workshops.

This project will develop resources for functional genomics in Polistes fuscatus wasps using a three-pronged approach. First, the researchers will use RNA-interference (RNAi) for ecologically relevant tests of candidate gene function. Functional genomic tests can be performed in the wild, allowing for assessment of gene function in an ecologically relevant context.  The project will improve RNAi efficiency through experimenting with technical parameters and biological conditions and test candidate genes for roles in phenotypes such as caste development and cognition. Second, the researchers will establish methods for controlled mating in the laboratory, and continuous rearing, aiming to contract the colony cycle, induce nest founding, and induce egg laying to provide continuous availability of insects for research. These developments will establish Polistes as a tractable model for rearing stable lines for functional genomics. Third, using gene editing with CRISPR/Cas9, the team will produce first generation (G0) wasps by injecting embryos and targeting the pigmentation gene yellow, with the goal of producing transgenic mosaics with non-lethal but readily observable phenotypic effects. Successful mutant G0s will be used to produce stable transgenic lines in the lab for yellow and then move on to other target genes of interest. This work may transform Polistes wasps into a functional genomic model system for numerous areas of organismal biology. The work is also unique in that it will allow for tests of gene function under controlled conditions in the laboratory as well as in the field, providing the major advantage of addressing how gene function depends on environmental context.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Polistes wasps, commonly known as paper wasps, are well-studied, cosmopolitan social insects.  Because of their abundance in human environments, ease of experimental manipulation, and developing genomic resources, these insects are poised to address many fundamental organismal biology questions (including speciation, behavior, development, neuroscience). This project developed multiple advances to facilitate the use of new genetic technologies in Polistes wasps in order to serve a growing community of researchers.  Main accomplishments of this project were as follows:

 

1.        We improved methods to alter wasp gene activity.  “RNA interference” is a valuable tool for examining gene function in live organisms, with the advantage of being able to “silence” genes at any time in a way that is short-lived and reversible, avoiding ethical issues associated with “transformation” approaches, i.e. genetically modified organisms. We advanced RNAi methods for the model social wasp Polistes fuscatus, a common North American species that is both an important pollinator, crop pest biocontrol agent, and household pest itself.  We began by optimizing a variety of parameters, including timing, dosage, and usage in multiple tissues and life stages. This allowed us to publish best practices guidelines which can be useful for doing similar work in other wasps, bees, ants, and insects in general.

 

2.        We made rearing wasps in the laboratory more effective. Coordinating between the labs of PI Toth and coPI Sheehan, we improved methods for getting wasps to mate in the laboratory, and discovered that social isolation prevents successful nest founding in the lab/ These developments are helping to establish Polistes as a tractable model for continuous laboratory rearing, which will be necessary if stable lines for genetic studies are to be created in the future.

 

3.        We made multiple advances that will allow genomic technology to be more widely applied to insects such as wasps. This included sequencing projects (including an improved genome for the North American invasive wasp Polistes dominula), the first-ever “atlas” of where genes are active in wasp brains (using single cell RNA-sequencing), and methods for injection of genetic “constructs” such as CRISPR/Cas9 and viral vectors into wasp tissues, opening new possibilities for future genetic manipulations.   

 

4.        We used RNA-interference to change gene activity in live wasps (specifically, expression of the yolk protein vitellogenin). We found that this gene alters wasp aggressive behavior, i.e. how much wasps fight with each other.  Thus, we were able to specifically identify a gene with a causal influence on wasp aggression. We also made a novel discovery, because this gene is only active outside of the brain (specifically, in head fat tissue), yet it has strong downstream effects on how genes turn on/off in the brain itself, and can alter behavior through a sort of “remote control”. As wasps are well known to fight for opportunities to become dominant and act as queen, this work is a model for how to study the genetics of an important adaptive behavior in a wild species.

 

Intellectual Merit. This work led to vast improvements in our ability to study genomics in a highly promising emerging model system, Polistes wasps.  We provided advances related to the use of RNA-interference, rearing methods, genomic sequencing, mapping gene expression down to the level of single cells in the brain, and also started on the path of tools for future ways to alter wasp genes, such as viral vector mediated gene transfer and CRISPR/Cas 9.  With the development of these “functional genomics” tools and their rapid and wide dissemination, this work can serve as a model for other species, and have a catalytic impact on a growing community of researchers interested in using social wasps to address a wide variety of questions in organismal biology.

 

Broader Impacts.  This work has helped to bring together the research community related to social insects and functional genomics through presentations, conference symposia, lab exchanges, and public protocol sharing.  It also provided training opportunities to several trainees at multiple levels of career development (undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral), and will endeavor to include members of underrepresented groups in these positions. We enhanced our project by creating a lab exchange program and an undergraduate research internship program (the Bee and Wasp Squad), as well as engaged in several public education and outreach programs to educate people about the importance of insect diversity, pollinators, and wasp ecology.  This work can also be of value for future efforts to use genetic approaches to control invasive social wasps, which are some of the most damaging pests worldwide.
